are we safer after 9 or 11 on september 11 2001 nineteen terrorist checked in for flight boarded four plane and then hijacked them the use of our own air travel system to attack the united state wa a shock to american and led to big question about the effectiveness of airport security check that allowed these men to board airplane with small hand weapon and tear gas airport security immediately changed in an effort to make air travel safer but have these change really made u safer listen to learn about the way security ha changed since 9 or 11 and way it can continue to improve about this resource this resource feature a real world public radio story listening comprehension question and classroom discussion theme about listen current listen current make it easy to bring authentic voice and compelling non-fiction story to the classroom we curate the best of public radio to keep teaching connected to the real world and build student listening skill at the same time for more information and teaching idea

newspaper comparison the same story from two different newspaper this pdf is designed to help student spot bias in reportage it can be used whole class and or or small group with a group who are well versed in language manipulation the exercise will need little explanation but those with le grounding in this area would benefit from a lesson or two discussing and researching emotive diction looking at advertisement and the emotional impact of image and word these two newspaper report focus on the same story and use the same detail but present them from wildly differing a priori position according to the political affiliation of the newspaper this is the start of a discussion regarding literary analysis and can lead into several common core writing area regarding argumentation and opinion piece

stamp act classroom simulation designed for middle schoolers this simple simulation help student actively engage in learning about the conflict between english colonist and king george give role card to each student king mp and colonist since student use a lot of paper each day it is easy to tax them and create a feeling of frustration give tax collector card that allow them to continually raise tax on the colonist if possible work with other teacher to allow the tax to be collected in other class a well the download is a pdf of the card to give to student to run the simulation use money from a board game or some sort of token for colonial currency tip do not carry out the simulation for too long grade conscious student will become very anxious about running out of money and being unable to turn in homework take note etc

cold war superpower face off power point and keynote presentation mr harm ha designed a number of powerpoint and keynote presentation to help student understand history designed by a teacher for teacher this powerpoint focus on cold war superpower face off this presentation is designed to give them an overview of the event leading up to and during the cold war student will be shown map animation and description of some of the major event leading to the cold war the presentation is totally customizable allowing you to add your own picture graphic and animation to take what we have done even farther it come with presentation note to help you discus the subject and engage them in the event of the cold war at le than $ 5 00 it will save you time and lay the foundation for presentation that help student understand and remember the topic include cold war yalta conference joseph stalin united nation security council united state soviet union communism iron curtain satellite country capitalism domino theory truman doctrine marshall plan berlin airlift nato warsaw pact berlin wall atomic bomb hydrogen bomb arm race brinksmanship icbm sputnik apollo number of slide 43 included in the presentation package 1 keynote presentation 2 power point presentation 3 text edit file of the outline of the presentation and presenter note the package is a digital download zip file of these three item we have a number of powerpoints related to the cold war teaching an entire unit on the cold war then check out our interactive cold war lesson plan these unit are proven to engage student in a way that text book and documentary can t hundred of teacher are using these lesson plan to bring history to life for student it s a unit you ll use year after year source mcdougal littel world history pattern of interaction perspective on the present restructuring the post war world chapter 33 section 1 cold war superpower face off go here to learn more

introducing student to bias fallacy etc in the argumentative research process over many year of teaching research method i have found that student shut down and stop really trying once they find one source for their topic this lead to frustration on the part of the teacher because the student ha not grasped all the concept necessary to submit an academically sound research paper this essay wa developed over a period of four year with a library colleague there have been many revision to the process however this product give not only faculty satisfaction but student gain insight and a new knowledge base for research by the end of the 5 week

link engineering linking k 1 2 to expertise and content the linkengineering website is an on line community of educator interested in providing meaningful engineering experience to prek-12 student of all ability linkengineering is a community of educator working with prek-12 student in classroom or other setting this includes but is not limited to teacher teacher educator and administrator the site allows member to connect with each other and engineering education expert linkengineering is a resource website that provides example of engineering in educational setting it also provides background information on engineering and engineering design

campbell ap biology chapter 55 reading game this reading game is helpful to teach student how to read for information and what information in the book is more important the section attached is for the campbell ap biology 8th addition but it could be modified for other textbook and addition reading game instruction assign page to student it can be 1-2 page up to an entire section allow the student time to read the page have the student close their book ask the question and then pick a random student to answer the question there are several random student name generator on line if the student get it right the student team get a point if the student get it wrong the teacher get a point keep track of point on the board the student can choose a name for their bell s team the teacher get a point for every time the class start to get loud or talk or that the teacher ha to tell them to be quiet the teacher can also get a point every time the class get caught cheating whoever ha the most point at the end of the game win if the student win they have no homework on a day of the teacher s choosing if the teacher win they have homework on the day that wa chosen another option is point added to an upcoming assessment this game can be played for any book and any section or chapter

endangered ocean concept the impact of human on the ocean provide insight into the effect that a population of seven billion ha on natural resource and the difficulty of managing an international commodity objective student will be able to list the principal pollutant in our world s ocean understand how human are altering ocean ecosystem draw connection between individual action and result at the global level develop strategy for minimizing and counteracting international environmental problem subject civics economics family and consumer science geography health history language art science social study skill critical thinking listening and observing role playing understanding because and effect method through an interactive story student experience the pollution of the ocean over time and critically examine way to protect and manage our ocean worldwide source

booknotes for the crucible about studymode studymode is the world largest learning community for student we we are founded in 1999 on the idea that learning is mean to be social we have built a platform for student to find to create and to share over 100m flashcard and 2m research document on common school subject studymode book note maybe you missed a class or maybe you just can not quite comprehend stream of consciousness style either way studymode com ha you covered when it come to free book note on the most widely read book in high school and college curriculum the crucible book note provide professionally written book summary including character plot summary analysis of major theme and a discussion of important theme and symbol you will also find quiz discussion question and suggested reading list to enhance your understanding of the material

civics primary and interactive resource for teacher and student this is a pearl of resource related to civics it contains assorted multimedia resource for student and teacher including glossary quiz game lesson plan and rubric a well a information about type of government and constitution of different country to curate this content i used pearltrees a free bookmarking service that let u user bookmark create and share web page file photo or note and organize them naturally you can also explore amazing collection that relate to your interest and subscribe to their update user need to create an account in order to access the pearl or collection the tool offer a bookmark let to add item to your collection and suggestion based on your interest this particular pearl spotlight primary resource official url and term related to civics

review video for stoichiometry for lower level chemistry the video wa made to review stoichiometry to lower level chemistry student who we are having a difficult time with the factor label method that is used in chemistry the method involves using a chart to separate the balanced chemical equation into mole mass volume and representative particle the video reminds student how to draw the chart and how to fill them in i had already taught the unit i uploaded the handout and the video to google doc and shared both on edmodo i have created these review video for every unit that i teach i have found that the student who need extra practice would actually work the problem out and then watch the video some student use the video to actually teach themselves how to do the problem student also enjoyed pointing out my mistake on most occasion i would not correct it it is good for the student to question the teacher i created this movie using active slate technology -- a movable promethian board it ha a record the screen feature you do not see me thank goodness that i can pause when i needed to do a calculation i have review video for each unit i teach with corresponding handout i have found that these video help student have better grade on test in fact once i find out that student are having difficulty with a particular lesson i try to make a video just on that piece of instruction virginia standard of learning chemistry ch 1 the student will investigate and understand that experiment in which variable are measured analyzed and evaluated produce observation and verifiable data ch 3 the student will investigate and understand how conservation of energy and matter is expressed in chemical formula and balanced equation ch 4 the student will investigate and understand that chemical quantity are based on molar relationship

the big renovation preview this is a free preview of a full-length video see how a house is built from the ground up learn about architecture framing electricity plumbing and all the tool it take to build a new house discover how tile are made and see a real sawmill in action even learn about termite my 3 1 or 2 year old really love this video i have several little mammoth video the publisher they are well written use child a narrator and are very educational the video discus the entire process of rebuilding a smaller home and modernizing it it is begun with an architect drawing the plan the demolition of the portion of the home that will no longer remain later aspect of framing sheet rocking following up by the architect and finish work damaged wood due to termite is discussed a well a an interesting visit to a university for a look at how termite follow smell i have a deep respect for little mammoth video a they do not get silly and maintain child attention throughout the movie customer review the big renovation is part of the award-winning big adventure series from little mammoth medium

microcosm of the scarlet letter i think the scarlet letter is a beautiful piece of literature with a wealth of analytical opportunity for student however student often find it unyielding and cumbersome the microcosm assessment requires student to participate in a multitude of close-reading analysis activity but with only 1 chapter of the novel what they do not read the entire novel blasphemy actually the plot especially when considered from a cccs perspective is le important than the literary component student are given a very detailed understanding of plot and character a well a a list of thematic development to fill the gap created by not reading the novel in it entirety using the prison door chapter the teacher model close-reading strategy emphasizing how to examine the novel for the literary device then student select a chapter and try it on their own what i most love about teaching hawthorne in this manner is that many student choose to read the novel on their own in the end which is a greater accomplishment than if they had read it a an assignment

operation lapis operation lapis is a two-year game-based impracticable introductory course in the latin language and in roman culture it may be employed on it own or a a supplement to other material program and teacher may experiment with it a a supplement and then easily transition to using operation lapis in place of a traditional textbook you are standing in the italian sunshine in a road in the distance rise a mountain so perfectly-shaped that it must be a volcano near the road is a tree and in the tree is a boy under the tree you see a rough-looking man the man look up menacingly at the boy and say ubi est lap thus begin a two-year epic adventure to find and to interpret the lapis saeculorum at the end of it the operative of operation lapis whether student playing in a traditional classroom or learner in cyberspace will read latin with fluency and understanding much more importantly they will know why their learning wa important and how they can use it to help save civilization and build their community

politics influencing the government the medium and special interest group this lesson teach the influence of the medium and interest group in politics and governmental policy student will be introduced to the tradition of first amendment protection of freedom of the press ha played in providing news outlet the ability to criticize the government and politician and how this protection is limited around the world student will then learn about the crucial citizenship responsibility to stay informed a this play an important role in voting student will learn how politician use the medium to push their agenda and campaign and the effect that medium bias play in obtaining objective political opinion student will also learn about public opinion poll and their influence in election and governmental policy this lesson trace the evolution of different form of medium and how more american are getting their news from the internet it also provides an introduction to the concept of propaganda and propaganda technique such a testimonial plain-folks appeal and bandwagon advertising or promotional campaign finally student will learn about watchdog role the medium play in exposing governmental corruption and wrongdoing this lesson also teach student the impact of interest group and the individual role in impacting governmental policy student will learn about the important responsibility that individual play in our democratic republic to run for elected office petition or write to governmental office holder attend political meeting volunteer for campaign make political donation and obviously vote student will be introduced to the creation of public policy and the role that interest group play in developing that policy they will learn about different type of interest group such a business labor union and public interest group example are provided such a the nea national education association naacp greenpeace the nra and now strategy such a lobbying electioneering litigation and publicizing of these interest group are introduced student are provided example such the naacp initiated brown v board of education lawsuit they will learn about the purpose function and potential downside of the lobbying industry

federal-republican system of the federative republic of brazil brazil and the united mexican state mexico to the dictatorship of the republic of cuba cuba distinguishing the form of leadership and the caribbean a explain how specialization encourages trade between country b compare and contrast different type of trade barrier such a tariff quota and embargo c explain the function of the north american free trade agreement nafta historical understanding s 6 h 1 the student will describe the impact of european contact on latin america a describe the encounter and consequence of the conflict between the spanish and the aztec and inca and the role of cortes montezuma pizarro and atahualpa b explain the impact of the columbian exchange on latin america and europe in term of the decline of the indigenous population agricultural change and the introduction of the horse s 6 h 2 the student will explain the development of latin america and the caribbean from european colony to independent nation explain the latin american independence movement include the importance of toussaint l ouverture simon bolivar and miguel hidalgo

you s constitution campaign commercial to meet the need of the core standard for argument and opinion writing a well a research and presentation skill student read informational text and historical document to research argument for and against the ratification of the you s constitution using this information they will then construct campaign commercial arguing for one particular perspective this is a creative endeavor for meeting several standard and core skill specifically addressing comprehension and collaboration and the presentation of knowledge and idea standard addressed research to build and present knowledge conduct short research project to answer a question including a self-generated question drawing on several source and generating additional related focused question that allow for multiple avenue of exploration gather relevant information from multiple print and digital source using search term effectively ass the credibility and accuracy of each source and quote or paraphrase the data and conclusion of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation draw evidence from informational text to support analysis reflection and research write argument focused on discipline-specific content introduce claim s about a topic or issue acknowledge and distinguish the claim s from alternate or opposing claim and organize the reason and evidence logically support claim s with logical reasoning and relevant accurate data and evidence that demonstrate an understanding of the topic or text using credible source use word phrase and clause to create cohesion and clarify the relationship among claim s counterclaim reason and evidence establish and maintain a formal style provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and support the argument presented

distance speed and time how to measure distance speed and time speed is how fast an object travel the unit of measurement include mile per hour mph kilometer per hour km or h and meter per second m or s we measure speed by finding the distance an object travel in one unit of time to calculate speed we divide the distance traveled by the time taken

mastering meaningful sentence a vocabulary lesson the mastering meaningful sentence lesson plan is more than just a simple vocabulary lesson instead is it a dynamic learning experience that engages student not in just memorizing definition but it establishing meaning using vocabulary in context and developing their writing skill in this lesson student learn that meaningful sentence are sentence that tell the reader something about a word and show that the writer understands the meaning of the word a meaningful sentence utilizes context clue to help the reader student will learn about type of context clue and crafting meaningful sentence in this multiple part lesson that includes the use of technology this lesson plan contains an anticipatory set where student explore how they best learn new vocabulary word through a quick write then student are introduced to writing meaningful sentence using the included google presentation a link to make a copy of the google presentation is provided so you can edit and modify to fit your class a pdf of teacher note for delivering the presentation is provided a well a two different handout to help student practice and then create their own meaningful sentence the lesson close with a quick activity on edmodo that allows student to share a meaningful sentence with their small group by teaching student how to craft meaningful sentence out of unknown vocabulary word you can not only improve their vocabulary but increase their use of new word in their writing this lesson can be modified to be used throughout the year for any type of vocabulary study i have had student choose their own unknown word from work of literature and create meaningful sentence and i have also assigned them word i want them to learn either way i have found this to be a great vocabulary activity to increase student engagement and learning

seismology the study of earthquake presentation and student graphic organizer this unit is designed not only to meet virginia standard but also common core and next generation standard this presentation will review geologic process resulting from plate tectonics specifically to earthquake student will be introduced to key term in seismology and their relationship to one another the presentation review tectonic boundary and introduces earthquake fault and seismic wave the presentation includes 3 slide for the teacher these slide have standard alignment link that can be used a resource and a link to a google slide version of this presentation the other 17 slide introduce seismology with definition graphic and animation a three page student graphic organizer is also included standard alignment va sol e 7 the student will investigate and understand geologic process including plate tectonics key concept include geologic process and their resulting feature and tectonic process common core cc ela-literacy rst 9-10 2 determine the central idea or conclusion of a text trace the text explanation or depiction of a complex process phenomenon or concept provide an accurate summary of the text cc ela-literacy rst 9-10 4 determine the meaning of symbol key term and other domain-specific word and phrase a they are used in a specific scientific or technical context relevant to grade 9-10 text and topic cc ela-literacy rst 9-10 5 analyze the structure of the relationship among concept in a text including relationship among key term e g force friction reaction force energy next generation science hs-ess 1 -5 evaluate evidence of the past and current movement of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate tectonics to explain the age of crustal rock topic covered earthquake epicenter main type of tectonic boundary main type of faluts main type of seismic wave and the subtypes

time bump i have provided a link to this game on my google drive a there is the game board game card and a direction page student can play time bump to practice telling time to 5 minute interval this make a great math workstation activity that can be differentiated for student at various level direction for time bump material needed game board game card and 10 token per student student will practice telling time to 5 minute interval using digital and analog clock print both the game board and the game card you can differentiate instruction by only using the digital card or the analog card or the word card when i use this game for review i use all of the card i also allow student to use classroom judy clock to assist with telling time place game card face down student will choose a card and identify the time on the card and then find that time on the game board they will place a token on that spot the next player will go if a spot ha only one token belonging to another player and you have that time on your card you can bump them off once a spot ha 2 token by 1 player that spot becomes frozen and if you land on it you lose a turn play is done when one player us all of their token

aztec inca maya this time line will focus on the three main civilization the mayan aztec and inca like other region around the planet central and south america saw their own civilization emerge the pattern of growth of civilization is the same a throughout the world domestication and agriculture lead to the first human settlement however a they had no contact with the civilization in africa asia and europe the american civilization had their own very distinct identity and culture

the battle of waterloo explore the battle of waterloo from the perspective of the duke of wellington sunday 18 june 1815 for the past three day napoleon ha been battling the force of the seventh coalition in belgium the french army ha pushed you the duke of wellington and your allied troop back to the entrance of the sonian forest you now occupy the plateau of mont-saint-jean knowing very well that napoleon will soon make his move from your headquarters you send a message to your prussian ally general von bl and muumuu teer hoping for his support in the upcoming battle with hstry timeliness you can integrate audio visual and chronological information in a way that is both creative and engaging student are exploring history in such a manner that allows them to integrate knowledge and technology and to build off of their information common core standard addressed craft and structure cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 4determine the meaning of word and phrase a they are used in a text including vocabulary specific to domain related to history or social study cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 5describe how a text present information e g sequentially comparatively causally cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 6identify aspect of a text that reveal an author point of view or purpose e g loaded language inclusion or avoidance of particular fact integration of knowledge and idea cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 7integrate visual information e g in chart graph photograph video or map with other information in print and digital text cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 8distinguish among fact opinion and reasoned judgment in a text cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 9analyze the relationship between a primary and secondary source on the same topic see this cool blog post

reaction lab for lower level chemistry the reaction lab is designed for lower level chemistry student the student work in group to perform two experiment chosen by the teacher with synthesis decomposition combustion single replacement double replacement and neutralization the student will record their first reaction on their phone or tablet and email it to the teacher the teacher will compile all of the clip into one movie to share with the class a the movie is played student will record their observation and complete the lab the lab is a culmination of the reaction and equation unit it is graded based on the completion of the data section 5 point each reaction equal 40 point 20 point on question 1 in analysis including the identification 5 point for each additional question and 15 point for the conclusion total of 100 not only is the lab on reaction and equation it also encourages student to follow written protocol and work with a lot of equipment technique is important however with these student the exposure to the equipment is more important virginia standard of learning chemistry ch 1 the student will investigate and understand that experiment in which variable are measured analyzed and evaluated produce observation and verifiable data ch 3 the student will investigate and understand how conservation of energy and matter is expressed in chemical formula and balanced equation ch 4 the student will investigate and understand that chemical quantity are based on molar relationship

the constitution nojust the fact welcome to constitutionfacts com where you will see the entire text of the constitution the bill of right and the declaration of independence and much more you will find interesting insight into the men who wrote the constitution how it wa created and how the supreme court ha interpreted the united state constitution in the two century since it creation the constitution is certainly the most influential legal document in existence since it creation some two hundred year ago over one hundred country around the world have used it a a model for their own and it is a living document it is one of the world oldest surviving constitution and while the supreme court continually interprets the you s constitution so a to reflect a rapidly changing world it basic tenet have remained virtually unchanged since it inception and unchallenged a well people quarrel over it interpretation but never do they question the wisdom of it underlying principle at constitutionfacts com you will begin to see why you will get a taste of some of the founding father thought you will see some of the reasoning behind the supreme court landmark decision but most importantly you will get a feel for the united state constitution itself and how it is that a document that wa written over 200 year ago still play an integral role in our everyday life

8 intro to problem solving video 8 of 17 math teacher circle are professional learning community of middle school math teacher and mathematician our goal is to help middle school math teacher confidently incorporate open-ended authentic mathematical problem solving in their teaching a math session is the heart of any math teacher circle meeting a two-hour session typically focus on an interesting and challenging problem that encourages collaboration among participant with varying skill level and background the video on this page is set up a play list of short clip drawn from a complete math teacher circle session the clip correspond to different activity or segment of the session and have been lightly edited to remove some participant work time and bring the overall length to approximately 1 hour 30 minute per play list each play list includes a debriefing session with participant and is linked to relevant resource including mathematical material from our site the play list is primarily geared for those learning how to plan and lead a math session including leadership team of new math teacher circle and people who have been invited to lead a session for the very first time we also anticipate that they will be useful to experienced session leader who want to learn more about a particular session a well a to anyone curious about math teacher circle in this video joshua zucker julia robinson math festival lead a math teacher circle session titled an introduction to problem solving josh present a problem that seems almost impossibly difficult but teacher discover many way to approach it by considering smaller simpler problem this video wa filmed in summer 2014 when 30 mathematician and math teacher from across the country came to a how to run a math teacher circle workshop at the american institute of mathematics in palo alto ca find material for this session here the 1 to 100 problem tom davis and joshua zucker an introduction to problem solving joshua zucker

periodic table of project in this project based learning opportunity student not only delve deeply into the periodic table but also have to pull on the ng crosscutting concept pattern to create their own periodic table why because it is not enough to just place random thing in a table-like arrangement they must also you must have an abstract that explains your periodic table it need to explain the trend in your table you must explain what each column or family in your table represents what the trend or periodicity is a you move across a row period you need to explain how your trend compare to the trend in the actual periodic table let your student creativity and organization skill shine

jim crow in the 1930s marian anderson and our nation capital in 1939 marian anderson an african-american opera singer wa prevented from singing to an integrated audience at constitution hall at the time washington dc wa a segregated city but did not have the white only sign familiar in the south anderson instead performed an outdoor concert at the lincoln memorial this public radio story describes the controversy over a recent child s book about anderson s concert at the lincoln memorial that showed colored only sign in place in public place you will hear from people living in the capital at the time talk about when the de facto racial segregation that did exist in the city wa exposed when marian anderson wa not allowed to sing in constitution hall about this resource this resource feature a real world public radio story listening comprehension question and classroom discussion theme about listen current listen current make it easy to bring authentic voice and compelling non-fiction story to the classroom we curate the best of public radio to keep teaching connected to the real world and build student listening skill at the same time for more information and teaching idea

tradition plus technology equal the perfect equation to flip your classroom john choins edmodocon 2015 during his 16-year teaching career john choins ha worked in both public and private school in the waco texas area for the last 11 year he s taught middle school math including algebra to regular and per-ap math student and wa chosen a the 2014-15 teacher of the year on his current campus a strong advocate for using technology to transform the teaching and learning process choins flipped his classroom in 2014 and based on the positive effect vow to never go back to the traditional way of teaching again wonder how a flipped approach can benefit your classroom choins share how he us edmodo to engage student with video practice exercise and photo-based assignment submission with step-by-step instruction you ll see how integrating technology creatively and efficiently add up what inspired you to apply to speak at edmodocon this past year i used edmodo almost every day with my student a a part of flipping my classroom i had never flipped my classroom before and i wa absolutely amazed at what a positive experience it wa for me my student and their parent i want to share my success and my love for edmodo with anyone who will listen when i saw the request for video submission and the opportunity to persent at edmodocon i jumped at the chance to share what i do on a platform that i love what s the one thing you hope people take away from your edmodocon persentation that flipping their classroom is possible it can be done with ease and it can make a huge difference in the education of their student

14 intro to problem solving video 14 of 17 math teacher circle are professional learning community of middle school math teacher and mathematician our goal is to help middle school math teacher confidently incorporate open-ended authentic mathematical problem solving in their teaching a math session is the heart of any math teacher circle meeting a two-hour session typically focus on an interesting and challenging problem that encourages collaboration among participant with varying skill level and background the video on this page is set up a play list of short clip drawn from a complete math teacher circle session the clip correspond to different activity or segment of the session and have been lightly edited to remove some participant work time and bring the overall length to approximately 1 hour 30 minute per play list each play list includes a debriefing session with participant and is linked to relevant resource including mathematical material from our site the play list is primarily geared for those learning how to plan and lead a math session including leadership team of new math teacher circle and people who have been invited to lead a session for the very first time we also anticipate that they will be useful to experienced session leader who want to learn more about a particular session a well a to anyone curious about math teacher circle in this video joshua zucker julia robinson math festival lead a math teacher circle session titled an introduction to problem solving josh present a problem that seems almost impossibly difficult but teacher discover many way to approach it by considering smaller simpler problem this video wa filmed in summer 2014 when 30 mathematician and math teacher from across the country came to a how to run a math teacher circle workshop at the american institute of mathematics in palo alto ca find material for this session here the 1 to 100 problem tom davis and joshua zucker an introduction to problem solving joshua zucker

physic from stargazer to starship ck 1 2 flexbook from ck 1 2 or flexbooks in physic this is the perfect supplement to any curriculum focused on history astronomy astrophysics and physic table of content stargazer and sun watcher this ssection defines east north south and west in term of the motion of the sun season are shown a a a consequence of the fact that sunrise and sunset migrate southward in the winter and northward in the summer the celestial sphere this ssection describes the apparent rotation of the night sky the role and position of the pole star and the difference between the motion of the star and element of the solar system -- the sun the moon and the planet the pole star this ssection describes the constellation of the big dipper and cassiopeia and their use in finding the pole star with some brief historical interlude the ecliptic this section cover the apparent motion of the sun moon and planet across the sphere of fixed star celestial sphere the concept of the ecliptic path of the sun along this sphere is described from different perspective making a sundial this chapter teach the design principle and orientation of a sundial it also provides instruction for creating a paper sundial season of the year this ssection show that the axial tilt of the earth varies the length of day and the angle at which the sun ray hit the same spot throughout the year giving rise to season the angle of the sun ray this ssection show that the greatest elevation of the sun above the horizon is at noon when the sun -- in the northern hemisphere -- is directly south of the observer the moon distant view this chapter provides a brief overview of the moon it apparent behavior and it role in time keeping the moon closer look this chapter provides an overview of the moon surface feature and a brief history of humanity discovery of these it also provides a brief overview of their exploration in the space age latitude and longitude introduces the concept of longitude and latitude navigation this ssection describes how astronomy wa used by early navigator for guidance the coordinate ssection introduces polar coordinate and relates them to navigation and the concept of longitude and latitude the cross staff this ssection describes the cross-staff an old device used to find one position on earth the calendar this ssection cover different method of keeping time a used by various civilization and explains them through the framework of periodic astronomical event precession this ssection describes the cause and effect of the precession of earth axis it review the history of humanity discovery of this phenomenon and then introduces modern theory of long-term weather change due to this phenomenon the round earth and columbus this ssection briefly describes the debate on the size of the earth and how this affected columbus voyage distance to the horizon this ssection cover the relationship between the height of object and the distance at which they can be seen from the surface of the earth the parallax this ssection overview parallax or the apparent change in position of an object in different line of sight it then show application how this phenomenon can be used to find distance between object estimating the distance to the moon this ssection describes how simple observation allow one to estimate the distance to the moon with a historical aside on the greek astronomer aristarchus it also overview the concept of eclipse distance to the moon 2 this ssection describes how solar eclipse can be used to estimate the distance to the moon a wa done by hipparchus doe the earth revolve around the sun this ssection show how aristarchus used the position of the half-full moon to estimate the distance to the sun and why this led him to believe that the earth may be revolving around it the earth shadow this ssection elaborates a statement from previous chapter -- why the fact that the sun is a disk influence the size of earth shadow during a lunar eclipse the planet this ssection introduces the various element of the solar system it also overview the planet and their apparent motion -- retrograde and pro grade

national archives-primary source and document help your student think through primary source document for contextual understanding and to glean information to make informed judgment the first few time you ask student to work with primary source and whenever you have not worked with primary source recently be sure to model careful document analysis direct student attention to the procedure involved and the kind of question you ask about the document after several instance of modeling ask student to work a a class to analyze document vocalizing the process a they go eventually student will internalize the procedure and be able to go through these step on their own every time they encounter a primary source document remind student to practice this same careful document analysis for every primary source they see for any type of document a written document image map chart graph audio or video move through the following step before getting into the content of the document look at it in a very general sense and ask basic question consider the document s type what kind of document are we looking at for example for textual document is it a newspaper letter report for artifact what material is this made of for video is it a propaganda film cartoon training video find unique characteristic of the document which will vary depending on document type note any marking or special quality these characteristic will help student understand the document in context for example are there any symbol letterhead handwritten versus typed text stamp seal or notation is there a background color or tone are there facial expression in photograph or other telling feature is there narration or special effect is there a key attempt to identify the creator and the content of the document break down the document by asking who what where when why and how rephrase the document into plain language student should determine the content of the document and speculate for whom and why it wa created help student understand the document in historical context

paul revere ride by henry wadsworth longfellow text and question henry wadsworth longfellow 1807-1882 wa an american poet this piece written nearly a century after the event occurred tell the story of paul revere whose ride through greater boston one night in 1775 helped spark the american revolution while not entirely historically accurate the poem popularized the tale most american know today told from the perspective of an innkeeper the poem recount revere s midnight ride a he warns colonist of approaching british soldier written in 1860 when america wa on the verge of civil war longfellow intended for the poem to be a call to action reminding supporter of the northern union that history favor the courageous

african imperialism simulation african imperialism activity lesson plan teaching a unit on the african imperialism for middle or high school student can be difficult it deal with event hundred of year ago and with foreign country student might only have a little knowledge of with the imperialism lesson plan student will get caught up in history a they represent various country who have interest in africa easy to set up this lesson plan can be customized to any size classroom mr harm produce interactive history lesson plan for high school and middle school student on a variety of subject key objective of the simulation activity a understand the inter-relationship between industrial production natural resource and market why imperialism happened b understand the general geography of africa c understand how the advancement of technology impacted colony and parent country the activity begin with 8 group representing european country at the start each country ha natural resource and industrial production that are equal in size group have the option of spending their national income on research and development to increase their industrial production their military for military conquest in africa or they may save some income for a later turn a each country make their move student are watching and learning from each other a industrial production grows income will only grow if market and natural resource grow at the same rate because this activity is made up of microsoft word and excel document it is completely customizable go here to learn more

freud theory of the id ego and superego text and question this famous theory of the structural model of the human psyche posit that human are controlled by their unconscious mind sigmund freud 1856-1939 is the most well-known psychologist that ever lived freud wa born to jewish parent in austria in 1856 and lived through world war i he died in 1939 at the beginning of world war ii during his life he wrote numerous book including the interpretation of dream many of which are still referenced by psychologist today freud is known a the father of psychotherapy a practice that involves questioning patient over a period of time to see what kind of memory may be influencing their behavior he is also credited for the development of the idea of the subconscious the deepest layer of the human mind said to be the place where memory wish fear and dream are stored

u homefront during wwii studystack for each set of flashcard entered the studystack website generates over a dozen way for user to study the information they need to learn the variety of study activity enables user to memorize data quickly without getting bored from using a single method of study studystack enables teacher to quickly enter data once and have a dozen different activity created for their student to memorize fact key term and idea about the united state homefront during wwii this government group wa set up to maintain morale and help organize civilian to help with the war effort office of civilian defense ocd this government group wa established to coordinate news and propaganda in the united state office of war information this government agency took over the nation economy and directed what wa made war production board wpb the use of information to sway people opinion propaganda the measure of the dollar value of all good and service produced by a country annually that mean every year gross national product gnp an artificial rise in price and cost of living this is a bad thing inflation government organization established to control worker wage and the price of good during world war ii in the united state national war labor board nwlb this statistic monitor the price change of certain good and service specific will be listed in prezi consumer price index cpi certificate that worker we are encouraged to buy to help fund the war effort they pay a certain price now and receive money back plus interest later war bond passed in 1942 this increased in corporate tax and the number of american who must now pay income tax the revenue act government restriction on who could buy item and how much they could purchase rationing 942 wa set up by government to set price ceiling on good office of price administration opa

the atomic mass of candy cornium the accompanying lab activity is designed for student to count measure and calculate the atomic mass of the fictitious element candy zirconium the student are asked several per lab question leading up to the step by step direction on the calculation after the counting measuring and calculating student will then have the atomic mass of candy zirconium and then do a percent error calculation i usually do this lab close enough to halloween that finding the candy corn and autumn mix is a bit easier to continue using the percent error equation i have the student use the accepted value that i come up with based on a random sample just like their random sample student are told to complete the lab with clean hand and clean cup and to keep the candy in the cup or the baggies if they so desire they can eat the lab of course this is a hit in addition the lab is completed after the atom and the calculation of atomic mass is taught student would have worked atomic mass problem and a quiz would have been given after instruction practice and lab to grade the lab i determine the correctness of the question both perlab and analysis a well a going through each line in the data table i would have each question worth 5 point and the data table 5 point per line ____ or 65 point virginia standard of learning chemistry ch 1 the student will investigate and understand that experiment in which variable are measured analyzed and evaluated produce observation and verifiable data ch 2 the student will investigate and understand that the placement of element on the periodic table is a function of their atomic structure

mesopotamia by the british museum the site is divided into ten chapter which address theme or topic relevant to the civilization of mesopotamia sumerian babylonian and assyrian the ten chapter are presented on a menu page where the user can choose a chapter by clicking on the word or icon relating to that chapter for each chapter there is a doormat page which is an atmospheric introductory page to the chapter the doormat page will automatically switch to the home page after a few second however clicking on the picture will switch it immediately the home page is an introductory page for the chapter within each chapter there are three section story explore and challenge the story is a presentation of information in a narrative form since the visual material surviving from mesopotamia is limited several of the story use specially-commissioned imaginative illustration the explore is a non-linear presentation of information the pupil control the order in which they access the information it is then the responsibility of the pupil and or or the teacher to make larger connection among idea and information and place the information in a context or framework the challenge is an activity that allows pupil to practice certain skill historical analytical mathematical observational within the context of a theme or topic relevant to mesopotamia

interactive biology notebook unit cell division moving science notebooking into the 21st century help student stay organized easily share student learning like a portfolio enable and encourage collaborative learning connect student with learning resource and give student more feedback about their learning biology interactive notebook this jam packed interactive notebook ha everything you need to teach your student biology divided into 10 unit an introduction to biology chemistry of life cell energy cell division protein synthesis genetics evolution ecology and classification unit 5 student proceed to look at cellular reproduction and study the process of meiosis and mitosis cell cycle mitosis meiosis what is included unit vocabulary cell cycle powerpoint fill in note and diagram mitosis powerpoint fill in note and diagram meiosis powerpoint fill in note and diagram

cell memory game color this 85-page resource contains color copy version the cell memory game focused on cell direction student need to match the picture and word with the definition this is an excellent pap or ap biology activity a well content this resource includes cell organelle state of osmosis four neurotic kingdom two proteolytic kingdom and specialized cell are covered there are 42 pair for a total of 84 card you can make smaller game to best suit your class need aligned to ng for grade 9-12 this resource could also be used to make flashcard for studying before a test the card are square and saved a a pdf by adjusting your page count per printed page you can adjust the size of your card i suggest laminating them and keeping them year after year i use one set per lab table so i printed 7 set you can have the student compete within a single table or between group below are the pair in the memory game general animal cell general plant cell general fungus cell general protist cell glenna nucleus rough endoplasmic reticulum smooth endoplasmic reticulum lysosome peroxisome ribosome golgi apparatus flagellum cilium microvilli special animal cell 4 pair animal and plant osmosis cell 6 pair special plant cell 3 pair special fungus cell 2 pair special protist cell 3 pair prokaryote 2 pair sex cell endocytosis and cytosine all artwork is hand drawn by me and available in color or black and white in a separate listing i have a black and white cell memory game available on spotlight this resource can also be found on teacherspayteachers

bowling for columbine analytical essay michael moore s bowling for columbine raise a number of issue when it come to use control and even how we a a society place the value and importance on gun these are presented sometimes a question and sometimes a statement of fact not everyone agrees with moore in his analysis of america and his analysis of canadian society living in canada we may find his portrayal of canada rather idyllic and limited or we may feel there really is a strong divide between american culture or crime and canadian culture or crime because our criminal code is so incredibly different when you compare the two country the simple truth is gun are part of our society and gun are an integral part to the canadian criminal code ccc why ha the issue of gun control been so political in canada why is gun control and the use of gun so intricately connected to the ccc even though this film is over a decade old now in this resource you will find the step by step instruction of how to use this documentary a a tool to explore the topic of gun control between canada and the united state and write an analytical essay this 9 page pdf file is intended to be used after watching michael moore s bowling for columbine student are asked to choose one of 5 topic or issue and approach it in an analytical and well-thought research essay of not le than 1500 word 4-6 page in this resource you will find the step by step instruction of how to use this documentary a a tool to explore the topic of gun control between canada and the united state and write an analytical essay also included in this resource is a 3 page video note or question guide an analytical essay outline 6-point scale criterion for written response and marking rubric

electroscope lab with differentiation how can an electroscope be used to determine electrical charge summarize the attached article to answer the question above building the electroscope thread the thick piece of wire through the hole in the rubber stopper bend the part of the wire that will be inside the flask into an l shape you will have to put this end into the flask so make sure it is not too big to fit through the opening carefully cut a strip of aluminum foil and drape it over the l part of the wire so that equal amount of the leaf are hanging on either side of the wire insert the wire with the aluminum foil strip into the flask and secure it with the rubber stopper there should be about 3 inch of wire showing above the rubber stopper make sure the aluminum foil is not touching the bottom of the flask next generation science standard p 3 b conservation of energy and energy transferwhen the motion energy of an object change there is inevitably some other change in energy at the same time ms-ps 3 -5 the amount of energy transfer needed to change the temperature of a matter sample by a given amount depends on the nature of the matter the size of the sample and the environment ms-ps 3 -4 energy is spontaneously transferred out of hotter region or object and into colder one ms-ps 3 -3 p 3 c relationship between energy and forceswhen two object interacting through a field change relative position the energy stored in the field is changed hs-ps 3 -5

beginning letter flip book this one title will allow your student to create 26 mini-booklets one for every letter of the alphabet the entire flip book for each letter is on one piece of paper which save on photocopy simply place the desired page on the copy machine press the button and hand the copy over to your student they color in the picture cut on the line put the page together and read the resulting booklet for example for the c book your student will track cat begin with c they then flip up the picture of the cat to reveal a picture of a car they then read car begin with c this continues with can cup and candy to give them five word in all that all begin with the same letter not only do they track the sentence and learn the beginning letter and sound they are able to compare capital letter and lower case this book also includes a reproducible chart which allows the teacher to keep track of the student a they progress through the book allowing them to work at their own speed and level each page is available a a black and white student reproducible a well a a full color teacher sample

survival of the cherokee primary source essay the you s government sent mixed message about the removal of native american from their land in 1830 the indian removal act gave president andrew jackson the right to negotiate removal treaty with indian tribe on the other hand in 1832 the supreme court ruled that the cherokee had the right to rule themselves here you will read two point of view from the debate over what wa best for the cherokee at the time you will answer the question what is the best way to save the cherokee way of life and culture using primary source material student will investigate the text to understand the cherokee debate regarding their best chance for survival the essay will focus on research and development of an argument citing source material to establish a clear thorough and persuasive argument this packet also come with a guide on how to write a five paragraph essay and helpful writing tip for struggling student standard cc ela-literacy whst 6-8 1 write argument focused on discipline-specific content cc ela-literacy whst 6-8 1 a introduce claim s about a topic or issue acknowledge and distinguish the claim s from alternate or opposing claim and organize the reason and evidence logically cc ela-literacy whst 6-8 1 b support claim s with logical reasoning and relevant accurate data and evidence that demonstrate an understanding of the topic or text using credible source cc ela-literacy whst 6-8 1 c use word phrase and clause to create cohesion and clarify the relationship among claim s counterclaim reason and evidence cc ela-literacy whst 6-8 1 d establish and maintain a formal style cc ela-literacy whst 6-8 1 e provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and support the argument presented

the reconstruction era and the fragility of democracy in the wake of the civil war american we are faced with the challenge of rebuilding a society that had been divided by slavery and the political upheaval of war the study of this period in american history is essential to the understanding of citizenship and democracy in the united state today facing history ha produced a series of video and accompanying lesson that will introduce a rigorous study of the reconstruction era into american history classroom our video series includes interview with scholar of the reconstruction era who provide insight into this complex history and address question of freedom justice equality and citizenship that are at the heart of the reconstruction we have also developed a complete unit that offer 16 lesson and many primary source document the unit available in print ebook and free pdf will guide student through a deep exploration of the reconstruction era while enhancing their ethical decision-making and capacity for emotional growth

solving quadratic equation by factoring this lesson is designed for the overhead projector but it is highly encouraged that you also reproduce these page for your student to take note along with you a you lead them through this lesson a teacher guide is included for convenient reference the lesson begin by introducing two parent that have just created a very perplexing situation for their young teenager who request a bigger room a compensation for the stress he is about to endure in an effort to convince his parent that his request is both reasonable and affordable he set up a quadratic equation and solves it by factoring ideally student should already have had some practice factoring binomial before beginning this lesson also assumed is an understanding of the foil method but the section referring to it can easily act a a quick mini-lesson for those who are seeing it for the first time discussion of the foil method is brief and this lesson by no mean depends on it mastery four problem are provided for independent practice you may very well add more from another source a you see fit i hope this provides an interesting context for your student a they learn an important strategy for solving equation hopefully you have some fun with it a well

the guernsey evacuation to england of june 1940 an overlooked wartime story the time line ha been created from a set of first hand account taken from a variety of people in order to give a clear view of how 17 000 guernsey child and adult experienced evacuation to the british mainland in june 1940 the story is told through the voice of an evacuated guernsey mother because guernsey wa only 30 mile from occupied france the fear of invasion wa very real the evacuee began to leave guernsey on 20 june 1940 and the island wa bombed by germany on 28 june and occupied two day later the evacuee remained in england scotland and wale for five year guernsey wa liberated on 9th may 1945 but due to the damage inflicted on the island by the german occupier the evacuee could not return home for month common core standard craft and structure cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 4determine the meaning of word and phrase a they are used in a text including vocabulary specific to domain related to history or social study cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 5describe how a text present information e g sequentially comparatively causally cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 6identify aspect of a text that reveal an author point of view or purpose e g loaded language inclusion or avoidance of particular fact integration of knowledge and idea cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 7integrate visual information e g in chart graph photograph video or map with other information in print and digital text cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 8distinguish among fact opinion and reasoned judgment in a text cc ela-literacy rh 6-8 9analyze the relationship between a primary and secondary source on the same topic

factory life in the north prior to the civil war video in the early 1800s the north and south of the you s began to drift apart from each other the section of the nation we are quickly becoming markedly different from one another the chief reason for this wa the rise of factory in the north which the south failed to adopt on a large scale this video describes how factory developed in the north and what it wa like to work on one outline changing life in the north geography slater and lowell factory life student will utilize this video to better understand the precise detail of explanation or description pertaining to the early event of the war of 1812 further they will better be able to determine the central idea of this point in history and provide an accurate summary of the event and individual involved in this complex moment in history video length approximately 10 minute

excerpt from narrative of the life of frederick douglas text and question frederick douglas 1818 1895 wa born a slave but became a social reformer abolitionist orator writer and statesman a a child douglas began learning to read and write with the help of his master s wife lucretia auld understanding the value of education he continued to teach himself after douglas escaped from slavery he became a leader of the abolitionist movement gaining note for his dazzling oratory and incisive antislavery writing he stood a a living counterexample to slaveholder argument that slave lacked the intellectual capacity to function a independent american citizen in this excerpt from chapter 11 of his book douglas describes his escape from slavery and the challenge he faced upon becoming a free man

cell r u project based learning experience that encourages student to learn about cell process in the context of creating a travel destination it is estimated that there are between 50 and 75 trillion cell in the human body cell make up all living thing cell need to carry on the same basic function a we do to sustain life the difference is cell do this with much smaller part these smaller structure that allow the cell to function are called organelle tiny organ also plant and animal cell have some similar part and some part that are not similar the design team of cell r u is attempting to create a travel destination that promotes awareness of cell among the general public you have been hired a a team of consultant for this project think of destination like amusement park ball park zoo farm mall etc there are certainly more possibility than this in order for your project to be considered by cell r u you must present a 3d model of your attraction with the following characteristic cell structure identification of the plant or animal cell organelle being displayed with justification for example the gigolo package secretion be sure to visit the golgi center inside the gift shop and have your purchase gift wrapped for you before you leave and image of the actual organelle diffusion osmosis and active transport an written explanation with visuals of how material and people travel to and from your attraction cell respiration a visual representation and explanation of how your attraction obtains energy includes access to resource and a teacher created mini-game

10 intro to problem solving video 10 of 17 math teacher circle are professional learning community of middle school math teacher and mathematician our goal is to help middle school math teacher confidently incorporate open-ended authentic mathematical problem solving in their teaching a math session is the heart of any math teacher circle meeting a two-hour session typically focus on an interesting and challenging problem that encourages collaboration among participant with varying skill level and background the video on this page is set up a play list of short clip drawn from a complete math teacher circle session the clip correspond to different activity or segment of the session and have been lightly edited to remove some participant work time and bring the overall length to approximately 1 hour 30 minute per play list each play list includes a debriefing session with participant and is linked to relevant resource including mathematical material from our site the play list is primarily geared for those learning how to plan and lead a math session including leadership team of new math teacher circle and people who have been invited to lead a session for the very first time we also anticipate that they will be useful to experienced session leader who want to learn more about a particular session a well a to anyone curious about math teacher circle in this video joshua zucker julia robinson math festival lead a math teacher circle session titled an introduction to problem solving josh present a problem that seems almost impossibly difficult but teacher discover many way to approach it by considering smaller simpler problem this video wa filmed in summer 2014 when 30 mathematician and math teacher from across the country came to a how to run a math teacher circle workshop at the american institute of mathematics in palo alto ca find material for this session here the 1 to 100 problem tom davis and joshua zucker an introduction to problem solving joshua zucker
